subs.text: May 5

Is abortion “deeply rooted in this Nation’s history and tradition?” Among people alive today, most of whom have lived their whole adult lives in a country where abortion was always constitutionally protected, yes it is very much deeply rooted.
subs.rawText: Is abortion “deeply rooted in this Nation’s history and tradition?” Among people alive today, most of whom have lived their whole adult lives in a country where abortion was always constitutionally protected, yes it is very much deeply rooted.

subs.text: @jeffjarvis @bluesky Software takes time. Replicating the functionality of a system that’s huge in complexity and scale while changing its underlying design, think about any other field, imagine rebuilding the nyc subway in a year or two with one of the basic constraints changed.
subs.rawText: @jeffjarvis @bluesky Software takes time. Replicating the functionality of a system that’s huge in complexity and scale while changing its underlying design, think about any other field, imagine rebuilding the nyc subway in a year or two with one of the basic constraints changed.

subs.text: @jeffjarvis @bluesky People expect miracles of software mostly because they don’t understand how it’s made but it’s pretty much like everything else, if it took a long time to make it the first time it’s going to take almost as much time the second and that’s assuming you’re cloning it.
subs.rawText: @jeffjarvis @bluesky People expect miracles of software mostly because they don’t understand how it’s made but it’s pretty much like everything else, if it took a long time to make it the first time it’s going to take almost as much time the second and that’s assuming you’re cloning it.

subs.text: @tconfrey @bmann @blaine OPML has been around since the late 90s. It's not a newcomer pretending to unify all previous formats. We were making lots of outlines, so we needed a format for interop.
subs.rawText: @tconfrey @bmann @blaine OPML has been around since the late 90s. It's not a newcomer pretending to unify all previous formats. We were making lots of outlines, so we needed a format for interop.

subs.text: @tconfrey @bmann @blaine I'm very interested in interop between outliners. [link] OPML is a widely supported format. I understand you prefer another format. Please concisely tell us more about it. Some example files would help. Is there a spec?
subs.rawText:
@tconfrey @bmann @blaine I'm very interested in interop between outliners. 

https://t.co/yYkHcrwgNf

Some example files would help. Is there a spec?

subs.text:
@JimMorrisonIAm @shanselman Not true. It depends who's writing and who's reading. I leave careful notes to myself because I know I'll need them. And I trust my collaborators to do the same. 

In any case I don't trust anything I read in code or comments. Esp not when I'm hunting down a bug.
subs.rawText:
@JimMorrisonIAm @shanselman Not true. It depends who's writing and who's reading. I leave careful notes to myself because I know I'll need them. And I trust my collaborators to do the same. 

In any case I don't trust anything I read in code or comments. Esp not when I'm hunting down a bug.

subs.text: @JimMorrisonIAm @shanselman My projects tend to be in development for many years, sometimes decades. Without discipline in documenting the work, you couldn't build on the code very far.
subs.rawText: @JimMorrisonIAm @shanselman My projects tend to be in development for many years, sometimes decades. Without discipline in documenting the work, you couldn't build on the code very far.

subs.text: The Supreme Court is protects the rights  of Americans. They’re not a religious body, they are not chartered to adjudicate religious questions, because there is no religion attached to our government. That part is in the text of the Constitution, for our textualist  friends.
subs.rawText: The Supreme Court is protects the rights  of Americans. They’re not a religious body, they are not chartered to adjudicate religious questions, because there is no religion attached to our government. That part is in the text of the Constitution, for our textualist  friends.

subs.text:
@shanselman I do, at the top of each major routine, it’s like a blog, with reverse chron notes about each major change. At the end of the list in the first comment is an explanation of what it does, params, etc.

And since it’s in an outliner, it’s all collapsed until you need to read it.
subs.rawText:
@shanselman I do, at the top of each major routine, it’s like a blog, with reverse chron notes about each major change. At the end of the list in the first comment is an explanation of what it does, params, etc.

And since it’s in an outliner, it’s all collapsed until you need to read it.

subs.text: @shanselman BTW, here's a source listing of the outline. [link] Scroll down to publishBlog and 2-click to expand it. You'll see the Changes section with a sequence of notes. Expand them to see what was done on that day.
subs.rawText:
@shanselman BTW, here's a source listing of the outline. 

https://t.co/xDQwLOvuHn

Scroll down to publishBlog and 2-click to expand it.

You'll see the Changes section with a sequence of notes. Expand them to see what was done on that day.

I'm glad @maddow has signed off four nights a week. Now there isn't one MSNBC host I'm addicted to. I watched Stephanie Ruhl last night and she's the best interviewer they have.

I think if people broke their addiction to punditry, we'd all do a lot better.

subs.text: I don't see why we have anything invested in Twitter continuing to work. What's the benefit? Are we dealing with our planet-scale problems any better that we would without it? Maybe letting it fall apart is the best thing. [link]

I don't see why we have anything invested in Twitter continuing to work. What's the benefit? Are we dealing with our planet-scale problems any better that we would without it? Maybe letting it fall apart is the best thing.

subs.text:
@bvschroeder Here's another clue. 

I pasted the text from the tweet into a new tweet here on twitter and it worked. 

i tried the same on a different website with a standard text edit box in chrome and it was mangled.

which strongly suggests it's a font issue. ;-)
subs.rawText:
@bvschroeder Here's another clue. 

I pasted the text from the tweet into a new tweet here on twitter and it worked. 

i tried the same on a different website with a standard text edit box in chrome and it was mangled.

which strongly suggests it's a font issue. ;-)

subs.text:
@bvschroeder From the CSS styles for the Wordle boxes.

font-family: TwitterChirp, -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, "Segoe UI", Roboto, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;
